attributes.comment:
Adjustment of the Immigration and Naturalization Benefit Application and
Petition Fee Schedule

I am the mother of 3 children adopted from Korea. I would like to address the
N-600 fee and forms for the Certificate of Citizenship, as it pertains to
adopted children who entered the United States on IR4 visas.

First, I do not feel there should be a need for an increase in the N-600 filing
fee in the case of IR4's. the reason being that these families have already
submitted all necessary documents for establishing our (the adoptive parents)
citizenship when we filed the I-600 A/I-600 form for the advance processing of
an overseas adoption. There should be no reason for 15 pages of re-submittal
and re-investigation of these files in order to obtain a COC on behalf of our
children. It is a waste of our governments time, money, and paper, not to
mention the adoptive parents'. I thought the goal was to eliminate waste in the
federal government?

We need to have some equality as it is not fair for families who adopt from
non-ally countries to receive FREE government services in the case of IR3
families receiving COC's on behalf of their children within 45 days of entry
with absolutely no paperwork required.

IR4 families, many who have adopted from South Korea ( an United States ALLY!),
are required to spend extra time and money to mostly duplicate the I600A and
send in our state issued adoption decree.

There needs to be a simplified form N-600 for IR4 families! It should only
require a one page form along with our submittal of a state issued adoption
decree. There is no need for USCIS to spend countless hours re-investigating
what has already been done. Just pull up the families I600, see that they had
I171-H approval to bring their child home, see that they have submitted their
official state issued final adoption decree, then issue the COC. Quite simple
really...why make it so hard on everyone involved with the current system.

Another problem with the current system is that families are required to appear
in person at the USCIS office. More NEEDLESS burden on the government agency
and the adoptive family as we have already appeared in person as part of the
I600-A advanced processing of an overseas adoption and for our the biometrics
submission.

Please consider addressing this issue, it should have been addressed before the
Child Citizenship Act of 2000 was put into effect on February 27, 2002.

Thank you for your time and consideration of these issues.

Sincerely,
Lisa Spinner, on behalf of my Korean born children Brandon, Matthew, and Sophia
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Lisa A. Spinner
